author: David Anderson
title: Sad day in Manchester United history when Danny Welbeck moved to Arsenal, says former teammate Darren Fletcher
text:
Sport Sad day in Manchester United history when Danny Welbeck moved to Arsenal, says former teammate Darren Fletcher Local-lad striker was just what a Reds player should be about, says West Brom midfielder also let go under Louis van Gaal Share Mancunian Welbeck came up through the United ranks, but Van Gaal had little use for him (Photo: Getty) Share     
Darren Fletcher claims selling Danny Welbeck was a “sad day” for Manchester United . 
Fletcher admits he was dismayed when then-manager Louis van Gaal offloaded Welbeck to Arsenal for £16million in September 2014, because the striker represented the club's ethos. 
The Scotland midfielder, who returns to Old Trafford with new team West Brom this weekend, claims Welbeck, now 26, was one of a number of players wrongly sold during van Gaal’s reign. New manager Van Gaal waved goodbye to Welbeck just weeks into his reign (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
“Lots of players who left under Van Gaal should still be there, in my view,” Fletcher told ESPN FC, echoing recent remarks by Van Gaal's successor Jose Mourinho. 
“That’s not me having a go at anyone, but the day Danny Welbeck was sold to Arsenal was a sad day. 
“He’s what a Manchester United player should be about - a local lad, young, great player, team player, somebody who sacrificed himself for the greater good of the team, loved by his team-mates. A 16-year-old Welbeck in FA Youth Cup action for his hometown club a decade ago (Photo: Man Utd/Getty) 
“He was on the brink of becoming a top, top player and he would have been a top player for United.” 
Fletcher, 33, was himself let go by Van Gaal in February 2015, and the midfielder says he knew the Dutchman did not fancy him. 
“I don’t think I was ever in Van Gaal’s plans in the first place,” he said. Fletcher said he had to leave United — but will be back with West Brom on Saturday (Photo: Getty) 
“I probably surprised him in pre-season and that enabled me to stay when a lot of other players left. But ultimately, I couldn’t stay and not play. 
“I would have been a bit-part player. That’s what I was for six months and it was really getting to me. 
"It wasn’t a case of me being patient, I just couldn’t see a way of out it. 
"I needed a new challenge.” poll loading Did Man United make a mistake selling Welbeck? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
